conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, we need to analyze their velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The distance between the two objects at any given time is the difference in their positions, which can be found by integrating their velocity functions over time.
Object A has a constant positive velocity, represented by a straight line.
Object B has a velocity that changes over time, represented by a curve.

premise: The position of an object is the integral of its velocity function.
conclusion: For Object A, since the velocity is constant, the position function is a linear function of time.

premise: The position of an object is the integral of its velocity function.
conclusion: For Object B, the position function is the area under the curve of its velocity-time graph.

premise: The distance between the two objects at any time \( t \) is the absolute difference between their positions.
conclusion: This can be visualized as the vertical distance between the two curves on the v-t graph.

premise: The maximum distance occurs when the difference in positions is greatest.
conclusion: This corresponds to the point where the area between the two curves is the largest.
At \( t_1 \), Object B starts moving in the opposite direction, increasing the distance from Object A.
At \( t_2 \), Object B changes direction again, moving towards Object A.

premise: At \( t_2 \), Object B changes direction again, moving towards Object A.
conclusion: The maximum distance occurs just before \( t_2 \), when Object B is moving away from Object A at the greatest rate.

premise: The maximum distance occurs just before \( t_2 \), when Object B is moving away from Object A at the greatest rate.
conclusion: The two objects are farthest apart at time \( t_1 \), when the area between the curves is the largest.
